critique: This document establishes a board to investigate a labor dispute between Pan American World Airways and the Transport Workers Union. It aims to prevent interruption of interstate commerce by ensuring no changes are made to the conditions of the dispute for a specified period. The document itself doesn't express a clear ideological stance, immigration policy, or prioritize national security over civil liberties. It seems primarily focused on resolving a labor dispute to maintain essential transportation services. It is difficult to assess the ideological tilt, immigration approach, security vs liberty, and social inclusion. The executive power is slightly expanded by creating the board, and federalism is slightly expanded as well. Economic regulation is also slightly interventionist.
